title: How to Paint a Garage

steps.headline: Clean your garage.
steps.description: This means power washing the outside and scrubbing the inside. If you are painting the garage floor as well, there are a lot of other things you need to do to prepare that surface. The last thing you want is to spend a lot of time and sweat painting your garage only to see the paint peeling and looking ragged next season. Do it right the first time.

steps.headline: Wear personal protective equipment.
steps.description: This means goggles and chemical resistant gloves and boots. You will need some pretty strong stuff to get that oil off the old concrete and get it ready to accept a coat of paint.

steps.headline: Ventilate the garage.
steps.description: The overhead garage door should be open, at least at the cleaning phase. If it is too windy, opening it up 6-8 inches (15.24 - 20.32 cm)should be sufficient to ventilate, but keep the outside from coming in and sticking to your new floor.

steps.headline: Mix a 3-1 solution of bleach and water to soak and scrub the floor.
steps.description: Let it sit for a few minutes before scrubbing. Make sure you rinse it well when you are done. Seal up any cracks and repair any damage to the concrete after the water has evaporated.

steps.headline: Pick your garage floor paint color and purchase the amount necessary to get the job done.
steps.description: By the time you get this all together, the crack repair and sealant should be completely dry. If not, give it more time. It has to be completely dry before you put down the paint. You may have to etch the floor if it is newer or does not readily absorb water. If it doesn't absorb water, it is not going to absorb the paint.

steps.headline: Apply a coat of primer after the floor is completely dry and ready.
steps.description: A primer will make your floor look 100 percent better and make it last longer. It is worth the time, effort and extra money. After at least 1 day, when the primer is completely dried, you can apply your paint. Make sure with both your priming and your top coat, you start from the back of the garage and work your way to the front so you can exit without walking over your masterpiece.

steps.headline: Power wash the siding first.
steps.description: Pay special attention to areas that have mildew or are badly stained.

steps.headline: Decide on your color and purchase a paint that is compatible with the type of siding you have on your garage, whether it is aluminum, vinyl, cedar plank or some other substance.
Paint from the top down, preferably using a power paint sprayer, which is more efficient than a brush or a roller for this application.
Prepare the interior walls and ceiling as you would inside your home.
steps.description: Patch holes, scrapes and tears with Spackle or joint compound. Sand it smooth and put a stain blocking primer undercoat on it.

steps.headline: Let the primer dry and then apply exterior paint.
steps.description: Do not use interior paint. Even though the inside of your garage is not exposed to the elements, it is neither protected as the inside of your home. Strong fluctuations in temperature and moisture content are too hard on interior paint.

text: Steps Clean your garage. This means power washing the outside and scrubbing the inside. If you are painting the garage floor as well, there are a lot of other things you need to do to prepare that surface. The last thing you want is to spend a lot of time and sweat painting your garage only to see the paint peeling and looking ragged next season. Do it right the first time. Wear personal protective equipment. This means goggles and chemical resistant gloves and boots. You will need some pretty strong stuff to get that oil off the old concrete and get it ready to accept a coat of paint. Ventilate the garage. The overhead garage door should be open, at least at the cleaning phase. If it is too windy, opening it up 6-8 inches (15.24 - 20.32 cm)should be sufficient to ventilate, but keep the outside from coming in and sticking to your new floor. Mix a 3-1 solution of bleach and water to soak and scrub the floor. Let it sit for a few minutes before scrubbing. Make sure you rinse it well when you are done. Seal up any cracks and repair any damage to the concrete after the water has evaporated. Pick your garage floor paint color and purchase the amount necessary to get the job done. By the time you get this all together, the crack repair and sealant should be completely dry. If not, give it more time. It has to be completely dry before you put down the paint. You may have to etch the floor if it is newer or does not readily absorb water. If it doesn't absorb water, it is not going to absorb the paint. Apply a coat of primer after the floor is completely dry and ready. A primer will make your floor look 100 percent better and make it last longer. It is worth the time, effort and extra money. After at least 1 day, when the primer is completely dried, you can apply your paint. Make sure with both your priming and your top coat, you start from the back of the garage and work your way to the front so you can exit without walking over your masterpiece. Exterior Garage Power wash the siding first. Pay special attention to areas that have mildew or are badly stained. Decide on your color and purchase a paint that is compatible with the type of siding you have on your garage, whether it is aluminum, vinyl, cedar plank or some other substance.  Paint from the top down, preferably using a power paint sprayer, which is more efficient than a brush or a roller for this application.  Interior Garage Prepare the interior walls and ceiling as you would inside your home. Patch holes, scrapes and tears with Spackle or joint compound. Sand it smooth and put a stain blocking primer undercoat on it. Let the primer dry and then apply exterior paint. Do not use interior paint. Even though the inside of your garage is not exposed to the elements, it is neither protected as the inside of your home. Strong fluctuations in temperature and moisture content are too hard on interior paint.
sentences: Steps Clean your garage.
This means power washing the outside and scrubbing the inside.
If you are painting the garage floor as well, there are a lot of other things you need to do to prepare that surface.
The last thing you want is to spend a lot of time and sweat painting your garage only to see the paint peeling and looking ragged next season.
Do it right the first time.
Wear personal protective equipment.
This means goggles and chemical resistant gloves and boots.
You will need some pretty strong stuff to get that oil off the old concrete and get it ready to accept a coat of paint.
Ventilate the garage.
The overhead garage door should be open, at least at the cleaning phase.
If it is too windy, opening it up 6-8 inches (15.24 - 20.32 cm)should be sufficient to ventilate, but keep the outside from coming in and sticking to your new floor.
Mix a 3-1 solution of bleach and water to soak and scrub the floor.
Let it sit for a few minutes before scrubbing.
Make sure you rinse it well when you are done.
Seal up any cracks and repair any damage to the concrete after the water has evaporated.
Pick your garage floor paint color and purchase the amount necessary to get the job done.
By the time you get this all together, the crack repair and sealant should be completely dry.
If not, give it more time.
It has to be completely dry before you put down the paint.
You may have to etch the floor if it is newer or does not readily absorb water.
If it doesn't absorb water, it is not going to absorb the paint.
Apply a coat of primer after the floor is completely dry and ready.
A primer will make your floor look 100 percent better and make it last longer.
It is worth the time, effort and extra money.
After at least 1 day, when the primer is completely dried, you can apply your paint.
Make sure with both your priming and your top coat, you start from the back of the garage and work your way to the front so you can exit without walking over your masterpiece.
Exterior Garage Power wash the siding first.
Pay special attention to areas that have mildew or are badly stained.
Decide on your color and purchase a paint that is compatible with the type of siding you have on your garage, whether it is aluminum, vinyl, cedar plank or some other substance.
Paint from the top down, preferably using a power paint sprayer, which is more efficient than a brush or a roller for this application.
Interior Garage Prepare the interior walls and ceiling as you would inside your home.
Patch holes, scrapes and tears with Spackle or joint compound.
Sand it smooth and put a stain blocking primer undercoat on it.
Let the primer dry and then apply exterior paint.
Do not use interior paint.
Even though the inside of your garage is not exposed to the elements, it is neither protected as the inside of your home.
Strong fluctuations in temperature and moisture content are too hard on interior paint.
